prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Detection of protoplanet candidates in HD100546. B6 CO, 13CO, C18O (all J=2-1) +cont.
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to observe HD100546 in the C36-8 non-standard configuration to achieve a 30 mas resolution. We aim to detect the kinematical features presented in Fig. 3 of the proposal and confirm the recently reported protoplanet candidates. This science goal will test CPD hydrodynamics with kinematical information from spectrally resolved gas emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have selected channels that are matched to the CO velocity dispersion near the CPD where gas temperatures are of order 80K.

Cycle 0 data on HD100546 published by Walsh et al. (2014) did not have the required resolution to detect the CPDs in CO. Their 0.95"x0.42" beam did show a clear picture of the bright CO disk but did not evidenced the presence of the companions. In order to detect the CPD signposts we need a finer beam, which at least approximates the size of the CPD. Our science goal does not require recovering scales larger than the Keplerian pattern loci around the candidate planets <0.5".

With a sensitivity of 2 mJy/beam in 0.476 km/s channels we can trace the disk kinematics and disentangle the CPD signpost, the offset CPD emission and the Keplerian twists shown in Fig.3 in the science case. We can trace enough emission to do this channel by channel, with a resolution similar to the CO thermal velocity dispersion. A crucial step in our science goal is to bin the channel maps in order to enhanced the CPD emission while decresing the global Keplerian emission. We can do this because the CPD emission arises from a fixed location in the disk (the size of a couple of beams in this configuration), while the global Keplerian pattern sweeps across the disk averaging out with thermal noise. This will bring the noise down which should allow us to detect the CPD kinematics. Our predictions are tied to the flux measured from previous CO observations by Panic et al. 2010 and Walsh et al. 2014.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Detection of protoplanet candidates in HD169142. B6 CO, 13CO, C18O (all J=2-1) +cont.
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to observe HD169142 in the C36-8 non-standard configuration to achieve a 30 mas resolution. We aim to detect the kinematical features presented in Fig. 3 of the proposal and confirm the recently reported protoplanet candidates. This science goal will test CPD hydrodynamics with kinematical information from spectrally resolved gas emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have selected channels that are matched to the CO velocity dispersion near the CPD where gas temperatures are of order 80K.

In order to detect the CPD signposts we need the finest beam, which at least approximates the total size of the CPD, which is about 40mas for the HD169142 candidate. Our science goal does not require recovering scales larger than the Keplerian pattern loci around the candidate planets <0.5".

With a sensitivity of 2 mJy/beam in 0.476 km/s channels we can trace the disk kinematics and disentangle the CPD signpost, the offset CPD emission and the Keplerian twists shown in Fig.3 in the science case. We can trace enough emission to do this channel by channel, with a resolution similar to the CO thermal velocity dispersion. A crucial step in our science goal is to bin the channel maps in order to enhanced the CPD emission while decresing the global Keplerian emission. We can do this because the CPD emission arises from a fixed location in the disk (the size of a couple of beams in this configuration), while the global Keplerian pattern sweeps across the disk averaging out with thermal noise. This will bring the noise down which should allow us to detect the CPD kinematics. Our predictions are tied to the flux measured from previous CO(2-1) observations by Panic et al. 2009 (SMA data)

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Recovering large scale structure in HD100546. B6 CO, 13CO, C18O (all J=2-1) +cont.
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This OT goal is complementary to the first 2 goals (which are the main science case). The purpose of this OT is to recover the large scale structure of the HD100546 disk in order to avoid any uncertainties with the image synthesis. We designed the OT for the C36-4 configuration which gives a resolution of 0.5" but this is not mandatory. A 0.7" configuration would provide the required large scale recovery.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have selected channels that are matched to the CO velocity dispersion near the CPD where gas temperatures are of order 80K.

This OT is aimed to recover the large scale structure of the disk seen in CO Cycle 0 data by Walsh et al. (2014). This is important to guarantee that a good image synthesis can be performed. 0.8" with the C36-2 configuration can recover the full size of the disk seen by Walsh.

With a sensitivity of 5 mJy/beam in a large beam in the C36-2 configuration we ensure a good signal to noise over the whole disk. With 0.476 km/s channels we can map the global kinematics of the disk.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Recovering large scale structure in HD169142. B6 CO, 13CO, C18O (all J=2-1) +cont.
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This OT goal is complementary to the first 2 goals (which are the main science case). The purpose of this OT is to recover the large scale structure of the HD100546 disk in order to avoid any uncertainties with the image synthesis. We designed the OT for the C36-4 configuration which gives a resolution of 0.5" but this is not mandatory. A 0.7" configuration would provide the required large scale recovery.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have selected channels that are matched to the CO velocity dispersion near the CPD where gas temperatures are of order 80K.

This OT is aimed to recover the large scale structure of the disk seen in SMA CO(2-1) data by Panic et al. (2008). This is important to guarantee that a good image synthesis can be performed. 0.8" with the C36-2 configuration can recover the full size of the disk seen by Walsh.

With a sensitivity of 5 mJy/beam in a large beam in the C36-2 configuration we ensure a good signal to noise over the whole disk. With 0.476 km/s channels we can map the global kinematics of the disk.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Witnessing a forming planet in a circumstellar disk is one of the three foremost ALMA Science Drivers. We propose to detect the gaseous circumplanetary disks (CPD) feeding accretion onto the two most promising protoplanet candidates: HD 100546b and HD 169142b. These protoplanets/CPDs have eluded detection, and their identification requires predictions on CPD gas tracers. With breakthrough angular resolutions, and informed by state-of-the-art 3D numerical simulations, we can test for the predicted CPD kinematics as deviations in the Keplerian signature of the disk gas. We propose to image these planet candidates at the highest resolution offered by ALMA Cycle-3 band-6 with the CO isotopologues. We assess the technical feasibility of this proposal by corrupting our CPD simulations with realistic phase and thermal noise, extracted directly from the recent HL Tau long baseline observations. Our proposed observations, informed by detailed simulations, would lead to a confirmation of these sources as forming giants, and provide fundamental tests on CPD hydrodynamics, by informing on the gas equation of state, and by constraining the size of the CPD and hence the protoplanets mass.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: No projects have been submitted on this science case to Cycle 3 by the PI or the team members.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: No ALMA proposals from previous cycles have been submitted that are related to this particular science case.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
